title: 110_hr853
content: The Act may be cited as the "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007". The Congress finds that improving population health and reducing medical costs requires preventive methods, there is a need for more public health professionals, only 6,000 physicians are board certified in preventive medicine, preventive medicine can help reduce costs spent on chronic conditions, the number of preventive medicine programs and professionals has decreased, preventive medicine physicians play a unique role in serving patients and communities, and a strong public health system relies on a strong preventive medicine workforce. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. Loan payment assistance is available for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may pay up to $20,000 of their medical education loans. Physicians must submit an application containing required information to receive this payment. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums may be appropriated for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 for loan payment assistance for preventive medicine physicians. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a wellness program employer credit. The wellness program employer credit under section 38 allows eligible employers to receive a credit of 25% of expenses for developing and implementing a qualified wellness program. The credit is limited to $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must maintain accurate records of preventive services and programs. An eligible employer is defined as one who develops and implements a qualified wellness program and keeps accurate records of employee participation. A qualified wellness program is one developed by the employer in consultation with a wellness program expert to protect participant privacy. The eligible employer must develop and implement a wellness program in consultation with a wellness program expert. The program should conduct health risk assessments, offer preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and provide counseling sessions and seminars on smoking, obesity, and stress management. The eligible employer's wellness program must offer annual counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics, with qualified participants including at least 50% of full-time employees. The eligible employer's wellness program must include counseling sessions and seminars on health topics, with qualified participants comprising at least 50% of full-time employees. Qualified employees are those who are full-time employees and participate in the employer's wellness program. Qualified participants are individuals who engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered. The employer's qualified wellness program defines a qualified participant as an individual who engages in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs and undergoes a health risk assessment. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The employer's qualified wellness program must be implemented. Section does not apply after December 31, 2012. Amendments made to the tax code to include wellness program employer credit. The amendments made by this section introduce a wellness program participant credit, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The wellness program participant credit allows a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who participate in a qualified wellness program. Qualified employees are defined as full-time employees who are qualified participants in the employer's wellness program. Qualified participants must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by the wellness program. The term 'qualified participant' refers to an individual who engages in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by a qualified wellness program and undergoes a health risk assessment. A 'qualified wellness program' is a program developed and implemented by an eligible employer in consultation with a wellness program expert. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes developing and implementing a program with privacy measures, conducting health risk assessments, offering recommended preventive services, and providing counseling sessions and seminars. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes offering preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, counseling sessions on various health topics like smoking, obesity, and mental health, and involving qualified participants. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers must cover preventive services, counseling on health topics like substance abuse and depression, and involve at least 50% of full-time employees. Eligible employers must develop and implement the program and keep accurate records of employee participation. The term 'eligible employer' refers to an employer who develops and implements a qualified wellness program and maintains accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and other programs. This section does not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. The amendments made by this section regarding the Wellness program participant credit apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
